document_title: Development of a size-separation technique to isolate Caenorhabditis elegans embryos using mesh filters
summary_full: This paper presents a novel protocol for synchronizing Caenorhabditis elegans (C. elegans) embryos using mesh filters, offering an alternative to the traditional bleach synchronization method. The bleach method, while common, can harm embryos and requires careful control of parameters. Microfluidic devices offer precise separation but are expensive and not easily scalable. The developed mesh filtration technique exploits size differences between C. elegans developmental stages to isolate embryos. Using sequential filtration with 40 µm and 20 µm mesh filters, the researchers achieved a higher yield of embryos per plate compared to bleach synchronization. They also optimized conditions by incorporating polyethylene glycol (PEG) into the M9 buffer to improve embryo pelleting and yield. Importantly, embryos collected via filtration showed no deleterious effects on downstream larval development assays and responded similarly to an anthelmintic drug as those obtained by bleaching. This method provides a scalable, cost-effective, and less harmful approach for obtaining synchronized C. elegans embryos for high-throughput assays.
key_findings: Developed a mesh filtration protocol using 40 µm and 20 µm filters to isolate C. elegans embryos, yielding approximately 9,500 embryos per plate, significantly more than the ~5,000 from standard bleach synchronization.
Incorporation of 3% PEG in M9 buffer increased embryo yield by threefold without negatively impacting embryonic viability.
Embryos collected via filtration developed into healthier and longer larvae after 48 hours compared to those obtained by bleach synchronization.

Filtration-derived embryos showed comparable or longer normalized animal lengths when exposed to albendazole, indicating similar drug response and developmental integrity as bleach-synchronized embryos.
The filtration method is scalable beyond microfluidic devices and avoids the harmful effects of bleach on embryos.
future_research_fields: Adaptation of the mesh filtration technique for isolating embryos from other Caenorhabditis species.
Optimization of mesh sizes for isolating C. elegans embryos with different dimensional characteristics.
Testing alternative bacterial strains for improved embryo retention on plates.
Further investigation into the effects of PEG concentration and other buffer modifications on embryo yield and viability.
Application of the filtration method for isolating other specific developmental stages of C. elegans.

conclusions: The developed mesh filtration technique offers a superior alternative to traditional bleach synchronization for obtaining large quantities of pure C. elegans embryos. It provides higher yields, avoids chemical stress on embryos, and ensures comparable or improved downstream developmental outcomes, making it suitable for high-throughput applications.
impact_statement: This study introduces a more efficient, scalable, and less harmful method for synchronizing C. elegans embryos, crucial for advancing genetic research, drug screening, and developmental biology studies in this model organism.
